metadata.title: Fabrication of Metal Molybdate Micro/Nanomaterials for Electrochemical Energy Storage

sections.text:
© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com (1 of 19) 1700917
Supercapacitors
Fabrication of Metal Molybdate Micro/Nanomaterials for Electrochemical Energy Storage Li Zhang, Shasha Zheng, Ling Wang, Hao Tang, Huaiguo Xue, Guoxiu Wang,* and Huan Pang*
Currently, metal molybdates compounds can be prepared by several methods and are considered as prospective electrode materials in many fields because the metal ions possess the ability to exist in several oxidation states. These multiple oxidation states contribute to prolonging the discharge time, improving the energy density, and increasing the cycling stability. The high electrochemical performance of metal molybdates as electrochemical energy storage devices are discussed in this review. According to recent publications and research progress on relevant materials, the investigation of metal molybdate compounds are discussed via three main aspects: synthetic methods, material properties and measured electrochemical performance of these compounds as electrode materials. The recent progress in general metal molybdate nanomaterials for LIBs and supercapacitors are carefully presented here.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The extent of molybdenum resources is rich on the earth. China has the largest proportion in the world, accounting for 44 per cent of known reserves. American follows closely, accounting for 28 per cent and Chile comes third, possessing 13 per cent. These three countries hence have the majority of the molybdenum resources. Apart from these three countries, the chemical element molybdenum’s reserves in Canada account for 5%. Russia and Armenia share the same proportion (2%). The other countries share the remaining 1% of the molybdenum resources. Metal molybdate compounds can be used as inorganic corrosion inhibitors, metal corrosion inhibitors, for corrosion testing and for photocatalytic applications.
Recently, metal molybdate compounds MMoO4 (M = Co, Zn, Mn, Fe, Ni, etc.) have proven to be remarkable materials in various fields, which has attracted the keen interest of researchers.[1] Nanocomposites with many metal molybdate compounds have been successfully synthesized,[2–6] taking advantage of the synergistic effects between the different metal molybdate components. Nowadays, a range of practical fabrication methods has been used to create specific metal molybdate compounds such as: hydro/solvothermal methods;[7–9] coprecipitation methods;[10,11] sonochemical methods;[12–14] combustion methods;[15,16] sol–gel methods;[17,18] solid-state methods.[19,20] In recent years, sonochemical methods and hydro/solvothermal methods have been extensively investigated to synthesize metal molybdate compounds.
Metal molybdates with stable crystal structure, redox behavior, remarkable physical/chemical properties and high electronic conductivity are one of the hottest topics in energy-storage fields.[21–23] In addition, Metal molybdates can also offer many advantages such as: providing direct current pathways; shortening the ion diffusion distance; lowering the charge–discharge time; increasing the electrolyte-electrode contact area; limiting mechanical degradation; accommodating volume expansion and contributing environmental friendliness; etc. In addition, Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) as the technology of choice for the world of portable electronic devices have had increasing impact.[24–28] Metal molybdate compounds have been prepared by several methods and have been considered as prospective electrode materials in many fields because the metal ions possess the ability to exist in several oxidation states.[18,29–31] LIBs deliver high-energy capacity by insertion/extraction of Lithium-ions and electrons in the electrode materials.[32–35] Therefore, the exploration and applications of metal molybdate nanotechnology is important to potentially increase the energy density of LIBs.[35–37]
Supercapacitors have been attracting intense attention as new energy storage devices in recent years,[38,39] because of their high power density, a wide various of applications, excellent electrochemical performance, extended cycle life, fast energy-storing and charge–discharge characteristics.[40–43] Supercapacitors change the power and energy density values of conventional capacitors or batteries.[44–47] In general, supercapacitors according to their charge-storage mechanism are classified into electrical double-layer capacitors
(EDLCs) and redox electrochemical capacitors (pseudocapacitors).[48–55] It’s said that extended cycle life is very significant by hybridizing supercapacitors with batteries in key situations. Thus, it is necessary to develop new electrode materials in supercapacitors, which can supply high-power, green energy-storage performance and extended periods of operating time.[56–59] Recently, metal molybdate compounds have been widely researched for supercapacitor applications owning to their excellent electrochemical performance, low cost, outstanding cycle stability and environmental benignity.[60–65]
In this review, we systematically summarize the synthetic methods of metal molybdates based on related materials, for example: Hydro/solvothermal methods;[7–9] coprecipitation methods;[10,11] sonochemical methods;[12–14] combustion methods;[15,16] sol–gel methods;[17,18] and solid-state methods.[19,20] Subsequently, the design and optimization of electrode materials are carefully discussed, followed by the evidence of electrochemical performance of these compounds (e.g., MnMoO4, CoMoO4, NiMoO4, etc.) as electrode materials. Metal molybdate compounds have been extensively attractive as promising electrode materials for LIBs. Besides, it has also been shown that metal molybdate compounds possess multiple oxidation states and high capacitances.[66] The multiple oxidation states are promising to prolong discharge time and improve energy density. Finally, conclusions and future perspectives to develop next-generation supercapacitors with higher performance are given. The recent progress of diverse metal molybdate nanomaterials for LIBs and supercapacitors is carefully presented here.

sections.heading: 2.1. Hydro/Solvothermal Methods
sections.text:
Hydrothermal method features a chemical reaction in a sealed reaction kettle with water as a solvent at high temperature and high pressure.[67] Its principle is mainly the dissolution recrystallization process. The hydrothermal method has the following advantages: (1) The hydrothermal method is controlled by the middle temperature liquid phase, the
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(3 of 19) 1700917© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
energy consumption is relatively low and the applicability is wide; (2) In the hydrothermal reaction, by adjusting the reaction temperature, reactant concentration, reaction time, pH and other factors, one can achieve the effective control of reaction and crystal growth characteristics, so as to obtain a product with a desired crystal structure and controlled particle size; (3) The product can be crystallized under hydrothermal conditions without the need for heat treatment, which can reduce the agglomeration of particles and the introduction of impurities. Hydrothermal methods are efficient for the development of high-quality metal molybdate compounds and we will describe these methods in greater detail in the following sections. Many nanostructures have been fabricated by a hydrothermal method.
For instance, Sakthikumar et al.[8] prepared Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials through the reaction of SnCl2 with Na2MoO4 in cetyl trim ethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) micellar media with sustained stirring. At first, 60 mL of 0.1 M Na2MoO4 and 0.434 g of CTAB were mixed together, then stirred continuously for about 30 minutes. Next, 60 mL of SnCl2 ethanol solution was added drop-wise and stirred for about 120 min at 60 °C. In the beginning, the solution was heated about 10 h at 120 °C in an autoclave vessel. Afterwards, the solution was cooled, washed, centrifuged, and dried at 80 °C and calcined at 500 °C. In addition, when the CTAB concentration was higher, the main morphology of the synthesized products particles was a needle-like Sn(MoO4)2. The formation of Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials by the hydrothermal methods is shown in Figure 1a.[68]
Besides, solvothermal method has also been widely used for the growth of metal molybdate compounds because of their large-scale production, simple processing, low cost, good scalability and excellent dispersion. Nevertheless, the growth orientation and crystal structure of metal molybdate compounds are not easily controlled.
By changing the experimental conditions, FeMoO4 nanorods have been fabricated via solvothermal method.[7] Firstly, 0.08 M FeCl2·H2O solution was added into 0.08 M Na2MoO4·H2O aqueous solution under magnetic stirring. The solution was located into an autoclave and kept at 120 °C, then cooled. Finally, the product was collected, washed and dried. The crystal structure of FeMoO4 is shown in Figure 2d.
In addition, a facile sonochemical approach was used for the synthesis of CoMoO4 nanostructures.
[9] Na2MoO4·2H2O, Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, ethanol and ethylene glycol were used as the precursors in the experiments. Firstly, 1 mmoL of Na2MoO4·2H2O and 1 mmoL of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O were dissolved together. Then, the above solution was transferred into an autoclave and kept at 150 °C. Subsequently, the solution was cooled. The black product was filtered, washed and dried at 500 °C for 4 h. The compound CoMoO4 was synthesized by this method.

sections.text:

solution is hydrolyzed to form insoluble hydroxides, oxides or other salts which precipitate, and the original anions in solution are washed away, followed by heat decomposition or dehydration, so that the desired oxide powder is obtained. Nanostructures such as SrMoO4 were synthesized through a simple coprecipitation method.[10] Firstly, Ba(NO3)2 aqueous solution was loaded with various surfactants, then CTAB was mixed together with the aqueous solution and heated at 70 °C. Subsequently, the product was collected, centrifuged, washed and dried at 60 °C. Hence SrMoO4 nanostructures were obtained.
For example, Ramezani et al.[11] used a coprecipitation method to synthesize ZnMoO4 nanostructures. The raw materials of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O were used as the precursor substances. Firstly, an appropriate stoichiometric ratio of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was stirred and dissolved in 20 mL distilled water. Afterwards, 7 mmoL of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and sodium dodecyl sulfate were mixed together as a surfactant and dissolved in distilled water with constant stirring. Subsequently, the total solution was cooled. Finally, the product was obtained, collected, washed and dried. The scheme for the formation of ZnMoO4 nanostructures is clearly demonstrated in Figure 1b.
This is a simple method in operation, with low requirements on equipment, easy to prepare in large quantities and not easy to pick up impurities. But the disadvantage is that the preparation particle size is very difficult to control and the size distribution and the surface properties are not uniform. It is very difficult to obtain the nanomaterials with good morphology.

sections.heading: 2.3. Combustion Methods
sections.text:
The combustion method mainly adds a quantity of organics in the preparation. The combustion of the organics emits a lot of heat to increase the burning temperature. At the same time organics will produce a lot of gas when burning, which can prevent self-aggregation of products, obtaining tiny-sized particles.
Vidya et al., via a modified combustion method, synthesized Ba0.5Sr0.5MoO4 nanopowder.
[15] Their starting materials of ammonia, polyvinyl alcohol, urea, carbohydrazide, oxalic dihydrazide, and glycine were used as fuel. Appropriate stoichiometric amounts of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Ba(NO3)2 and Sr(NO3)2 were used as the Mo, Ba and Sr sources and mixed together. The precursor solution was stirred and heated at 250 °C. Then, citric acid was added to the above solution as a complexing agent.[69] The above solution was heated to boiling and dehydrated as a foam. Subsequently, the samples were reacted by combustion synthesis. In this case, the asprepared powder was annealed at high temperature to get a pure powder.
Based on the above knowledge, Prabaharan et al. prepared Ni2(MoO4)3 framework compounds by a soft-combustion method.[16] Firstly, an appropriate stoichiometric ratio of Ni (NO3)2·6H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O were
mixed together. Secondly, the above solution and aqueous glycine were mixed together. When the solution was heated at 100 °C, a green colored solution was obtained. However, when the solution was heated at 250 °C, a dark green colored product was obtained. Furthermore, some combustible gases were liberated, which produced a brown powder. Then, the evolution of volatile combustible gases finally yielded an abundant product. The product was further annealed. Finally, pale green products were obtained. Ni2(MoO4)3 is an attractive compound due to its structure, magnetic and electrochemical properties.[70] Furthermore, these Ni2(MoO4)3 powders were obtained at a comparatively low-temperature, as shown in Figure 1c.
The products synthesized by combustion methods have the advantages of uniform particle size, low synthesis temperature and hence low energy consumption, but the cost to produce the product is slightly increased by the need to add organics.

sections.heading: 2.4. Sol–Gel Methods
sections.text:
The sol–gel approach has been used to synthesize organicinorganic hybrid materials or inorganic nanomaterials. Sol–gel methods include the gelatum of gelatinized colloidal solutions and solutions of other colloidal solutions in
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(5 of 19) 1700917© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
the liquid phase. During the sol–gel process, a sol prepared by mixing water with inorganic metal salts or metal salts is formed into a colloidal suspension Polymerization and/or hydrolysis reactions convert the liquid sol into a gel with a 3D network. The gel has a solid skeleton surrounded by an encapsulating liquid phase.
On the basis of the above, Pechini successfully synthesized LiFe(MoO4)2 by the sol–gel method.
[17] Firstly, MoO3 was dissolved in a mixed solution of NH3·H2O and H2O2 around 10 °C. Then, Fe(C2O4)·2H2O was dissolved in HNO3 solution Subsequently, the above solutions were mixed together, stirred and cooled, then citric acid was added into the combined solution and sustained at 60 °C to ensure the appearance of metal-complexes in the solution. Afterwards, ethylene glycol was added to the above solution and the temperature was sustained at 90 °C. The metal, citric acid and ethylene glycol were kept in an appropriate stoichiometric ratio. A gel was obtained, dried and decomposed at 300 °C. This was then converted to powder by calcination.
On the other hand, the sol–gel method have been used to synthesize CaMoO4 by Sharma et al.
[18] Firstly, a small amount of CaCl2 solution was added drop-wise to an appropriate stoichiometric amount of Li2MoO4 aqueous solution with stirring and heating in order to obtain CaMoO4 precipitate. The product was washed, filtered and dried at 160 °C for 24 h. Compared with the traditional methods, the sol–gel technique exhibits many advantages, such as low temperature, high purity and simple operation to obtain the final products of the process.[71]

sections.heading: 2.5. Sonochemical Methods
sections.text:
Sonochemistry is a new interdisciplinary subject, mainly referring to accelerating chemical reactions, or triggering the reaction events using acoustic pressure, in order to improve the chemical reaction rate or to obtain entirely new chemical reaction products.[72–75] The use of ultrasound can accelerate and control the chemical reaction, improve the reaction yield, change the reaction process and improve the reaction conditions and lead to new chemical reactions. It has gradually played an important role in the synthesis of many nanosized functional materials.[76]
As an example, Sadeghi et al.[14] synthesized the CuMoO4 by a sonochemical method. The Cu and Mo sources came from Cu(NO3)2·6H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, separately. In a typical synthesis, 0.20 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 0.27 g of Cu(NO3)2·6H2O were separately dissolved in adequate distilled water,. Then, the Cu(NO3)2·6H2O was heated. Afterwards, the (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O solution was added drop-wise to this solution with ultrasonic irradiation at 45 °C. A white precipitate was collected, filtered, washed, and dried at 60 °C for 60 minutes. The resultant nanospheres of CuMoO4 with large surface area and high electrical conductivity displayed a high specific capacitance and improved cycling stability.
In addition, Bazarganipour et al.,[13] using a simple sonochemical method, prepared BaMoO4 nanostructures. All the chemical reagents were raw materials without further purification in this experiment. During the synthesis process,
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
reviews 1.00 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 1.48 g of Ba(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in distilled water with constant stirring and divided into two beakers (C and D). Then, proline and leucine were added drop-wise to beaker D with continual stirring. The total solution was added to beaker C, then the solution was treated in an ultrasonic digestion system. Afterwards, the combined suspension was cooled and the product was collected, filtered, washed and dried.
Furthermore, CdMoO4 have been fabricated by a facile sonochemical method.[12] The Cd and Mo sources were Cd(NO3)2·6H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, respectively. In a typical procedure, 0.116 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O solution was dissolved in distilled water and 0.202 g of Cd(NO3)3·6H2O solution was dissolved in methanol solution. Then, the Cd(NO3)3·6H2O solution was heated and the (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O solution was added to this solution and the combined solution was heated at 45 °C. Finally, the total solution was treated with ultrasonic irradiation for 30 min. The resulting white precipitate was collected, filtered, washed and dried.
A pictorial diagram of the CdMoO4 structure is shown in Figure 2a. This structure is composed of eight symmetry elements and a body-centered orthorhombic primitive cell, in which each Mo and Cd site are surrounded by four O and eight O sites, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.6. Solid-State Reaction Methods
sections.text:
This is a traditional preparation method for molybdates, and early synthesis of molybdates extensively used this method. Zhou et al.,[77] through traditional solid-state reaction techniques, synthesized polycrystalline samples of Rb2Ba(MoO4)2. Appropriate stoichiometric ratios of MoO3, Rb2CO3 and BaCO3were thoroughly mixed together and added into a platinum crucible. The samples were heated at 600 °C and then cooled. Finally, the product was obtained.
The structure of Rb2Ba(MoO4)2 can be characterized as consisting of layers of MoO4 tetrahedra corner-sharing with distorted BaO6 octahedra, as shown in Figure 2b. These layers are perpendicular to the c-axis of the unit cell, and they are separated from each other by bi-layers of rubidium cations in a 10-coordinate environment which shares faces with the BaO6 octahedra.
A sample of MnMoO4 was synthesized by a conventional solid-state reaction method.[20] The reagents of MnCO3 and MoO3were used as precursor powders and were mixed together in appropriate stoichiometric proportions and then heated at 600 °C for 24 h. Finally, MnMoO4 crystalline
powder was obtained. A schematic diagram of the MnMoO4 structure is displayed in Figure 2c. The MnMoO4 structure has become known as alpha-MnMoO4, which consists of octahedrally coordinated Mn and Mo tetrahedrally coordinated by oxygen.

sections.heading: 3. Lithium-Ion Batteries
sections.text: With increasing energy demand, renewable energy storage plays an important role in the development of more powerful batteries.[80] Recently, LIBs have outperformed other systems.[32] LIBs have attracted much attention in some fields, because of their excellent electrochemical performance, lowcost, environmentally friendliness, high energy densities and design flexibilities. Transition metal molybdates have gradually been regarded as a substitute the commercial graphite anode for LIBs.[81,82] Metal molybdate compounds have especially attracted considerable attention as promising electrode materials for LIBs, because the great ability of metal molybdates to adopt various oxidation states.[83,84] Although most of these oxides are promising catalysts, but they are also attractive for electrochemical charge storage applications.[70,85] Specific capacities for various molybdate electrode materials in LIBs is shown in Table 1.

sections.heading: 3.1. Single Metal Molybdates
sections.text:
The low potential lithium insertion in metal molybdates and their application as electrode materials for LIBs is described in more detail hereunder.
FeMoO4 has been investigated as an important metal molybdate compounds, because its electrochemical applications in electrode materials for LIBs.[90] Furthermore, FeMoO4 has a high theoretical capacitance of 992.3 mA h g
−1 and high valences of Fe3+ and Mo6+. It was reported that FeMoO4 nanocubes could be used as an efficient and reversible lithium storage anode material, exhibiting remarkable rate performance and high capacitance of 926 mA h g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1 after 80 cycles, indicating a better prospect for LIB applications.[91]
Monoclinic FeMoO4 nanorods have been rationally designed and synthetized by a facile hydrothermal method.[79] The growth mechanism of the FeMoO4 nanorods is proposed in Figure 3d. At first, FeMoO4 nuclei and H2MoO4 were formed. After this, FeMoO4 grains merge into nanorods, and H2MoO4 decomposes into MoO4
2− and H+ at the same time, then MoO4 2− react with Fe2+ in order to form FeMoO4 grains.
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(7 of 19) 1700917© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
Finally, FeMoO4 nanorods gradually grow longer. The fieldemission scanning electron microscopic (FE-SEM) image of the sample showed the length of nanorods up to several micrometers, as shown in Figure 3a. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) image of the sample exhibits the FeMoO4 rod with only 50–150 nm width, as shown in Figure 3b.
The electrochemical properties of FeMoO4 nanorods was measured by galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves. Although there is a high theoretical capacity, the capacity rapidly faded from 1134 (2nd cycle) to 451 mA h g−1 (50th cycle), as shown in Figure 3c. Because of the appearance of stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film on the surface of the electrode and the irreversible destruction of the material structure, which led to irreversible lithium-ions interfacial storage and rapidly decreased capacity.[92] Then the capacitance gradually increased until it reached a value of 1265 mA h g−1 at the 500th cycle. After the 500th cycle, although the capacity gradually reduced, it still sustained a capacity of 1110 mA h g−1 at the 1000th cycle. Besides, in this period, the Columbic efficiency increased from 70% to 99%, which was ascribed to the stable SEI layer after about 50 cycles.[93]
The cyclic voltammogram (CV) curves of FeMoO4 nanorods display the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 50th, 500th and 1000th cycles of the GCD curves (shown in Figure 3e). Several peaks were observed from the cathodic curves: (1) in the 1st discharge reaction, the peak around 0.1 V was due to the SEI layer,[94] which disappeared after 50 cycles; (2) in the 1st discharge reaction, the broad peak between 1.5 and 2.0 V was attributed to the lithium-ions initially entering the crystal lattice and this peak then quickly disappeared;[95] (3) in the 2nd discharge reaction, the peak at 0.7 V was assigned to the reduction of Fe metal and retained its strength after 50 cycles; (4) the peaks from 0.2 to 0.4 V or from 1.2 to 1.4 V were attributed to the reduction reaction of Mo6+ to Mo4+ in both 50 and 500 cycles.[96,97] Most importantly, the anodic curves located at 1.5 and 1.8 V forming two broad peaks
gradually integrated into a single broad peak around 1.5 V after 50 cycles, which was associated with the oxidation of Fe and Mo metals. The peak gradually changed to 1.4 V by the 500th and 1000th cycle, indicating the polarization phenomenon beyond the 50th cycle.[98] The current intensity was the highest in the 500th cycle, according to the connection between the integrated peak area and the capacity, as shown in Figure 3e.[99]
Rate performance indicated that the FeMoO4 nanorods were a prospective commercial battery electrode candidate to replace existing anode materials in LIBs. This result indicated that the crystal growth of FeMoO4 nanorods was connected with nanosheets. Furthermore, the FeMoO4 nanorods indicated a higher specific capacity and conductive capacity, which made them as potential anode material for LIBs.
The FeMoO4 nanorods with well-controlled morphology and excellent electrochemical performance can offer high specific capacity, promote conductive capacity and increase cycling stability, which corresponds to the morphology and structure characterization.

sections.heading: 3.2. Binary Metal Molybdates
sections.text:
Some research indicates that the synthesis of single and binary metal molybdate nanomaterials has been widely developed. NixCo1−xMoO4 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1) nanowire electrodes were fabricated via a facile hydrothermal method.[86] The excellent electrochemical performance of NixCo1−xMoO4 nanowires as electrode materials of LIBs is shown in the following paragraphs.
Figures 4a to e show some representative FE-SEM images of NixCo1−xMoO4 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1) sample nanowire morphologies. In general, the lithium reactivity of molybdates has attracted increasing attention for their application as anode materials of LIBs because of their high reversible capacity. For further research the excellent performance of the NixCo1−xMoO4 nanowires, specific capacity curves were measured at a current density of 196 mA g−1 to verify the operation of Equation (1) in a potential window range from 0.01 to 3.0 V, as shown in Figure 4f. Compared to the CoMoO4 nanowires between 0.3 V and 0.01 V, the asprepared sample reacted with lithium in a potential window range between 0.4 V and 0.01 V in the 1st discharge cycle. Obviously, the 1st discharge capacities for Ni0.75Co0.25MoO4 and NiMoO4 were higher than their theoretical capacitance, which could be attributed to the SEI layer. Subsequently, the 2nd GCD curve was produced, in accordance with Equation (2). The NixCo1−xMoO4 nanowire electrodes possessed high reversible capacities, which provided evidence to deliver high capacity.
Compared to the reversible capacity of 290 mA h g−1 for NixCo1−xMoO4 (x = 0, 0.25 and 0.5), nanowire electrodes after 20 cycles, the reversible capacity for the NixCo1−xMoO4(x = 0.75 and 1) electrodes containing a higher Ni content increased reversible capacitance to 520 mA h g−1 after 20 cycles. Although the
NiMoO4 and Ni0.75Co0.25MoO4 nanowires have different surface area, they also have almost similar reversible capacities, which could be ascribed to the agglomeration of NiMoO4 nanowires. This method will promote combination with other electrode materials and offer many promising applications in electronic fields.
In addition, polycrystalline LiFe(MoO4)2 nanomaterial was successfully prepared by a solid-state method.[87] An appropriate stoichiometric ratio of Li2CO3, Fe2O3, and MoO3 were mixed together, and examined as electrode material for LIBs according to their GCD and CV curves. The cycling performance of LiFe(MoO4)2 nanomaterial was tested by GCD curves at a current density of 56 mA g−1and a voltage range from 3 to 0.01 V, as shown in Figure 5a. In the 1st discharge reaction, two flat plateaus around 2.57 and 1.74 V could be obviously found, which corresponds to the reduction reactions from Fe3+, Mo6+ to Fe2+, Mo4+, respectively. In the 1st discharge curve, the specific capacitance reached

771 mA h g−1 and the discharge curve became smooth without plateaus at low voltage. Afterwards, the plateaus around 2.57 and 1.74 V gradually disappeared, which suggested an incomplete structural transition.
Besides these effects, the 2nd discharge capacity displayed a higher specific capacity of 1034 mA h g−1, which corresponds to the theoretical capacity of LiFe (MoO4)2. Comparing the 2nd with the 1st discharge curves, the higher capacity of the 2nd discharge was ascribed to the irreversible electrochemical reaction. The cycling performance and Columbic efficiency of LiFe(MoO4)2 are shown in the inset of Figure 5a. In the 1st cycle, the specific capacity gradually decreased and stabilized at 580 mA h g−1 after 30 cycles. A loss of the irreversible specific capacitance at the beginning was observed, because of the impairing effect of electrolyte and the formation of SEI layer. Besides this, the poor conductivity also caused irreversible loss of lithium during the electrochemical processes.[17] The CV curves of the LiFe(MoO4)2 electrodes at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 and a voltage range between 0.01 and 3 V are as shown in Figure 5b.
In the 1st cathode scan curve, two clear reduction peaks around 2.60 and 1.74 V could be observed, because of the initial reduction reaction from Fe3+ to Fe2+ and Mo6+ to Mo4+.[100,101] With the scan voltage gradually decreasing, two reduction peaks around 0.76 and 0.26 V could also be observed, which are ascribed to the reduction to Fe and Mo metal and the SEI layering. In the anodic scan curves, a reversible oxidation peak was observed around 1.45 V because of the oxidation reaction from Fe to Fe3+ and Mo to Mo6+. Most importantly, it was hard to distinguish the reduction reaction peaks of Fe3+ and Mo6+, due to the fact that the oxidation peaks of Fe and Mo were similar.[102,103] Furthermore, because of the unreacted LiFe(MoO4)2 nanomaterials, a pair of redox peaks around 2.62 V and 2.13 V were clearly found in the 1st anodic scan curves and the 2nd cathodic scan curves, respectively, which led to better specific capacity in the 2nd discharge reaction. The 1st cathodic scan peaks around 2.60 V and 1.74 V, which indicated complete structural transition of LiFe(MoO4)2 nanomaterial’s followed by the next scan peaks gradually disappearing. In addition, the structural transition tend to keep stability after the 1st cycle, as shown in Figure 5b.
The LiFe(MoO4)2 nanomaterial electrodes have a high specific capacity of 1034 mA h g−1 at a current density of 56 mA g−1. Furthermore, because of the multi-electron reaction nature, LiFe(MoO4)2 nanomaterials deliver an excellent capacity performance which suggest scope for enhancement in the future.

sections.heading: 3.3. Graphene-metal Molybdates
sections.text:
Graphene with a 2D-carbon atom monolayer has been extensively studied as anode material[85,104] because its large specific surface area, high theoretical lithium storage capacity and excellent electrochemical properties.[105–109] In order to increase the capacity, researchers have synthesized a series of nanostructured transition-metal oxide/graphene composites. These composites display very good stability and
higher capacities, compared with their bare carbon material analogues. This phenomenon is attributed to the synergetic chemical coupling effects between the graphene with high electrical conductivity and transition-metal oxides with high lithium-ions storage capability.
3D-porous structures with larger surface area, higher electrical conductivity and lower density promise to be a better scaffold as a hybrid electrode.[110] Besides, 3D-graphene can increase the loading of active materials and offer enough space to adjust the stress relaxation by using the extra vertical dimension.[111] Compared with unstructured graphene, hybrid nanocomposites of 3D-graphene frameworks in LIBs have a long cycle life and superior stability. Although CoMoO4 has a high theoretical capacity of 980 mA h g
−1 as electrode materials in LIBs, its low electronic conductivity and poor capacities have limited its practical applications.[84] Besides this, 3D-graphene frameworks were used as a superior scaffold to host CoMoO4 particles (3–5 nm), which was beneficial to its electrochemical performance.
CoMoO4 nanoparticles doped on reduced Graphene oxide (CoMoO4NP/rGO) were obtained by a hydrothermal method.[88] The preparation process of CoMoO4NP/rGO nanocomposites is exhibited in Figure 6a. At the outset, in a typical synthesis, an appropriate stoichiometric proportion of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and H2MoO4 were dissolved together with distilled water by constant magnetic stirring. Subsequently, a large amount of NH3·H2O was added in the above solution in order to promote the formation of [Co(NH3)6]MoO4. Finally, the [Co(NH3)6]MoO4 was dispersed on the GO suspension. Because of the functional groups and defects of GO surface, the Co3+ and Mo6+ ions were adsorbed into the surface of GO after ultrasonication.[112,113] The CoMoO4 nanoparticles were fabricated and densely anchored in graphene sheets by the hydrothermal method.
The detailed morphology and crystal structural characteristics of the CoMoO4NP/rGO are studied by SEM, with a view as shown in Figure 6b. The porous structure demonstrated that the scaffold was built by the stacking of graphene sheets. However, the nanoparticles were not easily observed by SEM image and a subsequent high-magnification TEM image of the CoMoO4 crystal lattice is shown in Figure 6c. It is obviously observed that these tiny CoMoO4 nanoparticles are embedded onto the surface of graphene without aggregation, which leads to the formation of the hybrid CoMoO4 NP/rGO nanosheets.
The processes of lithium storage in CoMoO4 NP/rGO nanocomposites were studied by CV and GCD curves. Figure 6d shows the 1st, 2nd and 5th cycles for CoMoO4 NP/rGO in a voltage range from 0.01 to 3 V and a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. Some reduction and oxidation peaks in the CV curves can be clearly found, which indicates that the sample has a multiple reaction mechanism, as shown in the following Equations.[84,114]
+ → + +CoMoO 8Li Co Mo 4Li O4 2 (1)
+ ↔ +Co Li O CoO 2Li2 (2)
+ ↔ +Mo 3Li O MoO 6Li2 3 (3)
+ + ↔+ −C(graphene) xLi xe Li Cx (4)
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
1700917 (10 of 19) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews
In the first cycle, the five reduction peaks of CoMoO4 NP/rGO nanocomposites in the cathodic polarization process are shown in Figure 6d. The broad peak between 1.7 and 1.2 V can be ascribed to the destruction of the original crystalline structure and the reduction from Mo6+ to Mo4+. The intense peak around 0.74 V should be attributed to the further reduction of Co2+ and Mo4+ to Co and Mo, according to the reaction in Equation (1). The minor peak around 0.6 V could be assigned to the irreversible property of the solvent because of the existence of SEI layer.[115] The 5th cathodic peak around 0.01 V might be ascribed to the insertion of lithium-ions into the graphene nanosheets, according to the reaction of Equation (4).[114]
In the 1st anodic scan, the three anodic peaks at 0.13, 1.27 and 2.29 V were obviously observed. The anodic peak around 0.13 V corresponded to the extraction of lithium-ions from the graphene nanosheets, as shown in Equation (4). The electrochemical oxidation of Co to CoO and Mo to MoO3 leads to the anodic peaks at 1.27 and 2.29 V, as shown in Equations (2) and (3). This phenomenon also involves the reduction of CoO into Co and MoO3 into Mo, according to the reaction of Equations (2) and (3).[1,116] The GCD curves of the CoMoO4 NP/rGO (74%) nanocomposite presented in the 1st, 2nd, 5th, 10th, and 50th cycles at a current density of 74 mA g−1 are as shown in Figure 6e. In the 1st charge and discharge cycle, the GCD capacities of the CoMoO4 NP/rGO nanocomposite were 880 and 1250 mA h g−1, respectively. Initial capacities are extensively known for oxide anode materials. However, the discharge capacities of the CoMoO4 NP/ rGO nanocomposites were very close to the theoretical value of 918 mA h g−1. Furthermore, in the 1st discharge process, the initial irreversible capacities emerged because of the formation of SEI and electrolyte decomposition in a potential region of 0.5 V, as shown in Figure 6e.[84]
These advantages of higher electrochemical performance, better cycling stability and shorter lithium path length during the process of lithium insertion/extraction can be ascribed to the multi-layer porous structure and higher surface area of CoMoO4 NP/rGO nanocomposites. On the basis of such structural details, it is obvious that CoMoO4 NP/rGO nanocomposites are very promising as an anode material for LIBs.

sections.heading: 3.4. Metal Molybdates-PPy
sections.text:
The application of CoMoO4 nanoparticles as electrode materials in the LIBs has been investigated. However, during the process of lithiation/delithiation, CoMoO4 as an electrode material in LIBs has a lower conductivity and severe volume expansion.[117] On the basis of such observations, a simple approach has been reported to prepare the CoMoO4 nanocomposite with conducting polymer hybrid core-shell nanowire arrays on conductive carbon cloth as electrode materials for LIBs.
The schematic of the hybrid CoMoO4/PPy core-shell nanowire arrays on carbon cloth is shown in Figure 7a. Firstly, CoMoO4 nanowires was embedded on highly conductive carbon cloth via a simple hydrothermal method. Secondly, the layer of PPy was added onto the surface of the CoMoO4 nanowires.The morphological characteristics of the as-prepared sample were observed by SEM as shown in the image of Figure 7b. Further morphology and crystal structure details of the CoMoO4/PPy nanowires was revealed by TEM as shown by the image in Figure 7c. The thickness of outer PPy coating was about 65 nm.
The performances of the as-prepared samples as hybrid electrodes were measured by CV at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 in a voltage range between 0.01 and 3.00 V, as
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(11 of 19) 1700917© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
shown in Figure 7f. It was observed that the cathodic peaks were around 0.67 V and 0.01 V, which could be attributed to emergence of SEI layer and a reduction reaction following Equation (1).[27,118] Subsequently, the peak around 0.67 V decreased to 0.5 V and remained stable, then the peak around 0.1 V gradually disappeared, demonstrating the formation of SEI layer. Then, two anodic peaks were clearly found around 1.4 and 1.8 V in the 1st anodic sweep, which could be ascribed to the two oxidation reactions according to the Equations (2) and (3). In addition, the anodic peak around 1.4 V demonstrated the oxidation reaction from Mo to Mo4+, then the peak gradually shifted to 1.8 V, which should be ascribed to the oxidation reactions of Co, Mo4+ to Co2+, Mo6+, respectively.[119–121]
The electrochemical performance of the as-prepared samples was further investigated at various current densities between 100 and 1200 mA g−1 in Figure 7g. A high specific capacity of 1427 mA h g−1 was measured at a moderate current density (100 mA g−1). The capacity maintained at 753 mA h g−1 even at a higher current density of 1200 mA g−1. Besides this, in the discharge curves, the plateau appeared between 0.5 and 0.7 V, which matched the initial cathodic peak curves. In addition, a smooth voltage plateau was clearly observed between 1.5 and 1.8 V in the charge scan curves. Later, a voltage profile from 2.0 V gradually up to 3.0 V was obtainable, which indicates that the electrochemical performance of the as-prepared sample was even better than initially expected from theoretical considerations.
In order to indicate the practical applications of CoMoO4/ PPy nanowires, the as-prepared samples were used as anode materials in CoMoO4/PPy//liquid electrolyte//LiFePO4 LIBs. Firstly, the as-prepared material was used as an anode material, then LiFePO4 as a cathode material and 1 M LiPF6
was used as electrolyte, as shown in Figure 7d. The charge– discharge voltage cycling of the full batteries in the 1st, 2nd, 20th and 100th cycles at a current density of 100 mA g−1 in the voltage range 2.0 to 3.8 V, is as shown in Figure 7e. The full batteries also displayed superior charge–discharge capacity stability. The CoMoO4/PPy core-shell nanowire material used as electrodes for LIBs according to these analyses demonstrated excellent rate properties and high specific capacitance.

sections.heading: 4. Supercapacitors
sections.text: Recently, some flexible devices have attracted widespread interest because they are likely to change the nature of power supply devices in the near future. Flexible supercapacitors were fabricated by carbon-based nanostructures as active materials, such as carbon nanotubes, conductive polymers and graphene.[122,123] However, most of the carbonbased supercapacitors exhibit low capacitance and poor cycle life, which is unsuitable for practical applications. Therefore the improvement of cycling life, capacitance and active sites of flexible supercapacitors is still a great challenge.[57,124–126] Specific capacities for various novel electrode materials trialed in supercapacitors are as shown in Table 2.

sections.heading: 4.1. Single Metal Molybdates
sections.text:
The metal molybdates have been found to support potential applications in supercapacitors because they display several excellent properties, such as high power density, higher rate performance, larger surface area and smaller size and which
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
1700917 (12 of 19) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews
gives them potential for the next generation of electric power devices.[131,132] There is ongoing investigation of the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials for potential application in electrochemical supercapacitors.
Firstly, the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials were synthesized via a simple method.[68] The schematic formation of the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials via a hydrothermal method is shown in Figure 8a. The structural and morphological characteristics of the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials were measured by FE-SEM and TEM images. A FE-SEM image of the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials is shown in Figure 8b. The TEM image of the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanomaterials is shown in Figure 8c. From the TEM image of the sample, it is visibly observable that the lattice fringe is 0.316 nm and the average distance is 0.27 nm between two adjacent lattice planes. In the inset of Figure 8c, the electron diffraction pattern is shown, which indicates that the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 particles were crystalline in nature. Some separate individual spots cannot be observed here, but a ring-type pattern is obviously obtained. In the FE-SEM and TEM images, the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 particles are not completely mono-dispersed. The flakes adhering closely to each other may be ascribed to the presence of
some small quantity of surfactant in the original precursor mix.
The CV and GCD curves were included in the electrochemical studies, which were operated at room temperature. The batteries consisted of three electrodes: as counter electrode, reference electrode and a working electrode. In addition, the CV curves was measured at various scan rates between 5 and 125 mV s−1 and a potential window from 0 to 0.65 V. The GCD curves were obtained at various current densities between 0.8 and 5 mA cm−2. Some active materials, carbon and polyvinylidene fluoride were mixed together in appropriate proportions to prepare the working electrodes. The weight of active materials was 2–3 mg.[133]
The specific capacitance value of the flake-like nanostructures of Sn(MoO4)2 was 109 F g
−1 at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. The flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanostructure electrodes had increased specific capacity because of their high surface area, which provided a large amount of active sites for charge storage. The polarization and Ohmic resistance were obviously observable in measuring scans, by altering the scan rate of the flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanostructured electrodes at various scan rates between 5 and 125 mV s−1. During the redox processes, the irreversibility was as shown in Figure 8d. When the scan rates were gradually increased, the position
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(13 of 19) 1700917© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
of the anodic peak changed to a higher potential and the cathodic peak also shifted, but to a lower potential. This phenomenon indicated that the ionic diffusion rate was not fast enough to keep pace with electronic neutralization in the redox reaction.[134]
In order to know much more about the rate capability, the specific capacity of electrodes at various current densities was measured and can be seen in the Figure 8e. The capacitance value of flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanostructure electrodes were calculated to be 30 F g−1 at a current density of 0.8 mA cm−2. The robustness of the device at high-current densities, such as 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 mA cm−2, and were observed that the specific capacitance values were 22.9, 20, 17.3, 13.5 and 12.8 F g−1 respectively. It can be seen that the specific capacitance decreases with the increase in current density. The cycle stability of flake-like Sn(MoO4)2 nanostructure electrodes is an important attribute for applications as a supercapacitor material.

sections.heading: 4.2. Graphene–Metal Molybdates
sections.text:
Among various Co-based materials, ternary CoMoO4 has been regarded as an ideal candidate with a high theoretical specific capacitance of 980 mA h g−1, with synergistically enhanced electrochemical properties including electrical/ ionic conductivity and mechanical stability.[135] Specifically, a Co nano-cluster matrix not only impedes the gathering of Mo nanocrystals into large grains, but also serves as a cushion to reduce volume transformation and structural stress during the charge–discharge processes.[136]
Nowadays, more and more researchers are giving the most intense attention to the metal molybdates because of their various significant properties.[70,137] For example CoMoO4 compounds have brilliant electrochemical characteristics. Xia
et al.[138] used a single-step hydrothermal method to prepare CoMoO4/graphene (CoMoO4/G), as shown in Figure 9e. The CV curves of CoMoO4/G composite show a specific capacitance of 395 F g−1 at a scan rates of 1 mV s−1.
Carbon or graphene are proposed as new materials to change surface properties in order to improve irreversible capacity, due to the active materials ineffectively alleviating the large stress caused by the volume expansion.[139–142] Graphene is a new carbon material with high surface area,[143] and carbon/graphene coatings can reduce the impediment for lithium-ions to reach the core of active materials.
Graphene was used as a conductive substrate in order to get a higher ratio surface area for composites by Xia et al.[127] Additionally, graphene’s high electrical conductivity has been used for new electrode materials for supercapacitors.[144,145] Graphene has also been focused on as a precursor for graphene. Therefore, Xia et al.[127] fabricated CoMoO4/G composites by a single-step hydrothermal method. In addition, the groups of G sheets provided some active sites in order to anchor the Co2+ ions. CoMoO4 nanoparticles were grew on the G sheets at the same time with the synthesis processes. The CoMoO4/G nanoparticle composite was obtained, which presented a higher surface ratio to volume and larger active sites. The CoMoO4/G nanoparticle composites exhibited a better performance than pure-CoMoO4 as electrode materials, which indicated the CoMoO4/G nanoparticle composites might be excellent electrode materials in the field of supercapacitors.
To know much more about the rate capability, the scan rates of CV curves were investigated between 1 and 100 mV s−1 and the potential range between −0.75 and +0.25 V. The GCD curves were investigated at various current densities of 0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2 A g−1 in the potential range between −0.75 and +0.25 V. For comparison, the as-prepared CoMoO4/G composites were measured at a current density of 1 A g−1 after 500 cycles in KOH electrolyte.

www.advancedsciencenews.com
1700917 (14 of 19) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews
The morphological features of the as-prepared sample composites were studied by TEM and SEM observations. The TEM images of CoMoO4/G reveal that the composites consist of an uneven dispersion of CoMoO4 nanoparticles with a size range from 20 to100 nm, as shown in Figures 9a and b, respectively. It can be obviously observed in the SEM image that the CoMoO4 nanoparticles have a very uneven dispersion on the graphene sheets, as shown in Figure 9c.
The CV curves of CoMoO4/G nanoparticles at different scan rates of 1, 5, 10, 20, 40, 60, 80 and 100 mV s−1 are demonstrated in Figure 9d. With the potential sweep rates gradually increasing in speed, the cathodic peaks changed positively and the anodic peaks moved in a contrary direction, which demonstrates the resistance of the electrodes. In addition, with the potential scan rates gradually increasing, the current density through the CoMoO4/G nanoparticles increased obviously, which indicates excellent capacity and rate properties of these CoMoO4/G nanoparticles. On the basis of such knowledge, we take it as proven that the conductive graphene not only strengthens the charge transport but also promotes the greater utilization of CoMoO4/G.

sections.heading: 4.3. Metal Oxide–Metal Molybdates
sections.text:
Transition metal compounds with superior electrochemical characteristics have been widely used as supercapacitors electrode materials.[146] MnO2 is a promising candidate as an electrode material for supercapacitors because of its superior
electrochemical performance, such as low cost and natural abundance.[147] However, it’s also reported that the performance of nanostructured MnO2 as the electrode material in supercapacitors is unsatisfactory.[148,149] In order to solve this problem, some composites were formed in the hope of enhancing the electrochemical performance. NiMoO4 also displays superior electrochemical performance. By some research, combining NiMoO4 with MnO2 can enhance the electrochemical performance, conferring a higher electron diffusion efficiency, desirable cycle life, rich accessible active sites, excellent rate performance and superior synergetic properties beyond the single components.
Pure MnO2 nanowires and NiMoO4 nanoflakes were formed by a hydrothermal method.[150] The preparation of a hierarchical MnO2/NiMoO4 core-shell nanostructure is depicted in Figure 10e. Firstly, a solution of KMnO4 is reacted with NH4Cl solution at 180 °C for 20 h in order to obtain MnO2 nanowires. These MnO2 nanowires were formed via a hydrothermal reaction according to Equation (1).[148] Afterwards, NiMoO4 nanoflakes were synthesized on the surface of the MnO2 nanowires as per Equation (2). Urea was added as a precipitating agent, MnO2 nanowires served as a backbone and the hierarchical MnO2/NiMoO4 core-shell nanomaterials were formed by a hydrothermal reaction at 110 °C for 12 h.
+ → + ↑ + +2KMnO 2NH Cl 2MnO N 2KCl 4H O4 4 2 2 2 (1)
+ → +NiCl Na MoO NiMoO 2NaCl2 2 4 4 (2)
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
(15 of 19) 1700917© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.com
While further investigating the electrochemical performance, SEM images of hierarchical MnO2/NiMoO4 core-shell nanostructures were taken, as shown in Figure 10a. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) microanalysis on selected areas was undertaken to confirm the composition of MnO2/ NiMoO4 compounds as shown in the inset of Figure 10a. The high magnification TEM morphology of hierarchical MnO2/ NiMoO4 core-shell nanostructures is shown in Figure 10b, in which a layer of ultrathin NiMoO4 nanoflakes are loaded uniformly on the surface of MnO2 nanowires. The blank area without NiMoO4 covering on the surface of MnO2 nanowires might be ascribed to the ultrasonication before the TEM examination. An examination of the SEM and TEM images clearly indicated that MnO2/NiMoO4 core-shell nanostructures with a diameter of 165–210 nm and the shell of ultrathin nanoflakes interconnected with each other, which provided open and porous three-dimensional structures in favor of electrolyte accessibility and electron transportation during the electrochemical reaction processes.
The CV curves were obtained to quantify the properties of hierarchical MnO2/NiMoO4 core-shell nanostructure at various scan rates between 5 and 30 mV s−1 in KOH electrolyte, as shown in Figure 10c. With the potential scan rates gradually increasing, CV curves were obviously not distorted even at the highest scan rates, which indicates the excellent cycling stability of MnO2/NiMoO4 electrodes. In addition, GCD curves of MnO2/NiMoO4 were evaluated from 1 to 10 A g−1 in a voltages range between 0 and 0.45 V as shown in Figure 10d.[151,152]
On the basis of such knowledge, the MnO2/NiMoO4 electrode has obvious advantages over the single structural electrode materials, exhibiting a high capacitance of 187 F g−1 at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1.The results indicate that the MnO2/ NiMoO4 electrode exhibits excellent supercapacitor performance with superior cycling stability, super-long cycling life and high capacity.

sections.heading: 4.4. Coupled Single Metal Molybdates
sections.text:
The metal molybdates, such as MnMoO4 and CoMoO4 have superior catalytic and electrochemical characteristics.[152,153] At present, coupled single metal molybdates have been widely focused on for supercapacitors.[154–157] Coupled single metal molybdates can improve the electrochemical performances for supercapacitors, because of the synergistic effects over single metal molybdates.[157] MnMoO4/CoMoO4 nanowires were synthesized via a simple refluxing method. MnMoO4 nanowires were the backbone of material, and the CoMoO4 shell thickness could also be changed by changing the molar ratio of Mn and Co source. Mai et al.,[156] by a facile refluxing method, synthesized MnMoO4/CoMoO4 nanowires, which demonstrated superior stability and a specific capacitance of 187 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1, as shown in Figure 11a. The specific capacitance of 187 F g−1 was higher than MnMoO4 (9.7 F g −1) and CoMoO4 (62.8 F g −1). Furthermore, the synergistic effects and cycling stability for the coupled electrode materials allow scope for further studies. The excellent performance of the mixed metal molybdates is worth further investigating in supercapacitors.
SEM images of MnMoO4/CoMoO4 heterostructured nanowires have been obtained, as shown in Figure 11b. Besides these, TEM images of the MnMoO4/CoMoO4 heterostructured nanowires have also been obtained, as shown in Figure 11c. The high-resolution TEM investigation indicates that the interlayer distances are consistent with the interplanar distances of CoMoO4 (0.335 nm) and MnMoO4 (0.288 nm). These results demonstrate that the as-prepared sample of nanoscale MnMoO4/CoMoO4 was a well-crystallized heterostructure. The excellent electrochemical performance of hierarchical MnMoO4/CoMoO4 nanowires was demonstrated by CV and GCD curves. The GCD curves of hierarchical MnMoO4/CoMoO4 heterostructured nanowires in NaOH electrolyte are displayed in Figure 11d.
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
1700917 (16 of 19) www.small-journal.com © 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
reviews
small 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
As reported, the active sites of the electrode materials could be easily visited by ions or electrons because of the low resistance at low current densities. In addition, high specific capacity values were easily achieved. However, the high current densities play an important role in industrial applications, so the as-prepared sample were investigated at higher current densities. Under these conditions, the as-prepared sample electrodes still indicated a high capacity.
The charge storage mechanism of MnMoO4/CoMoO4 nanowires was studied via CV curves. The CV curves obtained from MnMoO4/CoMoO4 nanowires are shown in Figure 11e. Redox currents gradually increased with the increasing scan rates. Furthermore, the anodic scan curves changed to more positive potentials at faster scan rates, whereas the cathodic scan curves changed to more negative potentials. The peak current curves indicated that ionic transport and the rates of electronic reactions both increased rapidly at a scan rates of 100 mV s−1.
In short, the as-prepared sample of MnMoO4/CoMoO4 nanowires have been investigated in detail and indicate that such samples have excellent applications in electrochemical and charge storage devices.

sections.heading: 4.5. Ternary Metal Molybdates
sections.text:
To date, many molybdate-type compounds have been obtained and widely investigated for energy storage. Most of these materials have been synthesized under harsh reaction conditions. There are few reports about synthesis under mild conditions to yield useful morphologies. Attention is now turning to investigate the electrochemical performance of controlled morphologies of ternary metal molybdate
compounds for use in supercapacitors. Therefore, the Li2Co2(MoO4)3 3D-framework is reported here.
A Li2Co2(MoO4)3 3D-framework was prepared as a possible electrode material for supercapacitors. This electrode materials exhibits an excellent capacitance and high cycling ability in LiOH electrolyte. The interconnected nanorodnanoflakes morphology also appears to enhance the electrochemical performance of Li2Co2(MoO4)3. The electrode materials of 3D-framework Li2Co2(MoO4)3 materials were grown in conductive substrate in the supercapacitor.[158,159] The conductive substrate was considered as a current collector in order to promote fast electron transport. The illustration growth process of the as-prepared sample was showed in Figure 12a.[130]
The nanorod-nanoflake Li2Co2(MoO4)3 was prepared by a hydrothermal method, as shown in Figure 12d. FE-SEM and TEM images of the nanorod-nanoflakes Li2Co2 (MoO4)3 are exhibited in Figures 12b and c. The nanoflakes were grown on to the nanorods and attached to the nanorods and indicated that the nanorods and nanoflakes were formed a continuous solid material. The SEM image was used to indicate the impurity distribution and particle sizes of the phase.
The performances of the nanorod-nanoflakes Li2Co2(MoO4)3 were tested by using CV and GCD curves. The CV curves were measured at different scan rates in the potential range 0.1 to 0.5 V. The CV curves of the interconnected nanorod-nanoflakes Li2Co2(MoO4)3 samples in 2 M LiOH electrolyte before and after calcination at 350 °C are shown in Figure 12e. The sample indicates two anodic peaks located at 0.2 and 0.3 V, respectively. Besides these, the samples also displayed two cathodic peaks around 0.05 and 0.18 V, respectively. This phenomenon demonstrated that the process is fully reversible because it contained two
(17 of 19) 1700917© 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.small-journal.comsmall 2017, 1700917
www.advancedsciencenews.com
redox couples. However, when the current densities were gradually increased, the peaks positions of the as-prepared samples changed and the anodic and cathodic scan peaks were at 0.15 and 0.12 V, respectively. This phenomenon demonstrated an electrochemical property of the nanorodnanoflakes Li2Co2(MoO4)3 electrode materials.
[160] By comparison with the uncalcined counterpart which was annealed at 350 °C, more resolved redox peaks could be obviously observed in the CV curves, as shown in Figure 12e. This phenomenon might be attributed to the crystallization and open tunnel formed by water removal, which allowed ions to easily embed into the bulk materials.[161] The CV curves of the samples exhibit that a charge storage process of induced current was carried out in these electrolytes. The GCD curves of the as-prepared sample were conducted at different current densities from 1 to 50 A g−1.
Onto study the influence of ion size on the electrochemical performance, some measurements of GCD curves were done in different electrolytes, such as NaOH and KOH. It was clearly observed that the specific capacitance gained in lithium-based electrolyte was higher than those in Na-based and K-based electrolytes, which corresponds to the CV curves results, as shown in Figure 12f. This phenomenon could be ascribed to the small size and the mobility of lithium-ions in the crystal structure, which was more easily intercalated.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
There is no doubt that a basic understanding of metal molybdate electrode structures, their electrochemical properties, and their charge storage mechanisms is indispensable for metal molybdate relevant research. In addition, the behavior of electrons, ions in the active electrode materials and electrolyte transport need to be further studied. Nanosized particles rather than bulk materials need to be employed in most cases due to the following reasons:
(1) The small size-scale materials can reduce the physical strain in the process of lithium-ions insertion/extraction.
(2) High surface area allows higher contact area between the electrolyte and electrode, thus improving the reaction kinetics.
(3) Nanomaterials can significantly shorten lithium- or sodium-ion diffusion path lengths compared with their bulk counterparts.
Furthermore, coupled metal molybdates can also improve the electrochemical performance of supercapacitors, because of the synergistic effect of individual metal molybdates, in order to get excellent performance of electrode materials.
Molybdates are a strong anodic oxidation inhibitor, because their oxidation is much weaker than other anionic groups, and their toxicity is very low. In aqueous electrolytes, molybdates are non-oxidizing or weak oxidizing inhibitors. There an advantage of molybdates in small potential pollution to the environment. Disadvantages are that their corrosion inhibition effect in some combinations is poor, the price is currently expensive and when used alone, the amounts required are too large to be economical. Therefore, further
clever designing and simpler synthetic methods to increase the effective surface area and further reduce circuit resistances of electrode materials are still major challenges.

referenceMentions.context: Nowadays, a range of practical fabrication methods has been used to create specific metal molybdate compounds such as: hydro/solvothermal methods;[7–9] coprecipitation methods;[10,11] sonochemical methods;[12–14] combustion methods;[15,16] sol–gel methods;[17,18] solid-state methods.[19,20] In recent years, sonochemical methods and hydro/solvothermal methods have been extensively investigated to synthesize metal molybdate compounds.

[60–65] In this review, we systematically summarize the synthetic methods of metal molybdates based on related materials, for example: Hydro/solvothermal methods;[7–9] coprecipitation methods;[10,11] sonochemical methods;[12–14] combustion methods;[15,16] sol–gel methods;[17,18] and solid-state methods.[19,20] Subsequently, the design and optimization of electrode materials are carefully discussed, followed by the evidence of electrochemical performance of these compounds (e.
Then, citric acid was added to the above solution as a complexing agent.[69] The above solution was heated to boiling and dehydrated as a foam.

metadata.abstractText: Currently, metal molybdates compounds can be prepared by several methods and are considered as prospective electrode materials in many fields because the metal ions possess the ability to exist in several oxidation states. These multiple oxidation states contribute to prolonging the discharge time, improving the energy density, and increasing the cycling stability. The high electrochemical performance of metal molybdates as electrochemical energy storage devices are discussed in this review. According to recent publications and research progress on relevant materials, the investigation of metal molybdate compounds are discussed via three main aspects: synthetic methods, material properties and measured electrochemical performance of these compounds as electrode materials. The recent progress in general metal molybdate nanomaterials for LIBs and supercapacitors are carefully presented here.
